title: 107_hr2342
content: The "Primary Care for Children Act of 2001" is cited as the short title. It amends the Public Health Service Act to provide patient access to pediatric care through pediatricians. The "Primary Care for Children Act of 2001" ensures that group health plans offering pediatric care must allow parents or guardians to designate a pediatrician as the primary care physician for children under 18. This designation does not waive coverage requirements for medical necessity or appropriateness. The "Primary Care for Children Act of 2001" mandates that group health plans must allow parents to designate a pediatrician as the primary care physician for children under 18, without waiving coverage requirements for medical necessity or appropriateness. Amendments to ERISA further address pediatric care coverage. "SEC. 714. PATIENT ACCESS TO PEDIATRIC CARE." Patient Access to Pediatric Care: A group health plan must allow a parent or guardian to designate a pediatrician for primary pediatric care for beneficiaries under 18 years of age. This designation does not waive any coverage requirements related to medical necessity or appropriateness for pediatric care. The group health plan must allow a parent or guardian to designate a pediatrician for primary pediatric care for beneficiaries under 18 years of age, without waiving coverage requirements related to medical necessity or appropriateness. A clerical amendment is made to the table of contents in the Act. Sec. 9813. Patient access to pediatric care. Amendments made to the Internal Revenue Code to ensure access to pediatric care for beneficiaries under 18 years of age. Patient Access to Pediatric Care: Group health plans must allow parents or guardians to designate a pediatric primary care physician for beneficiaries under 18 years of age. This designation applies to primary pediatric care benefits provided by a participating physician specializing in pediatrics. The plan must still adhere to coverage requirements for medical necessity and appropriateness. The amendments made by this section apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 2003. Enforcement actions will not be taken against a group health plan or insurance issuer for violations before regulations are issued, as long as they have made a good faith effort to comply. The amendments made by this section apply to plan years starting on or after January 1, 2003. For group health plans under collective bargaining agreements ratified before the enactment of this Act, the amendments do not apply until the last agreement terminates or January 1, 2003, whichever is later. The collective bargaining agreement amending the plan to comply with new requirements will not be considered a termination of the agreement.
